title: rtemislive
text:
Welcome

Welcome to the rtemislive online documentation.
 
rtemislive is the graphical interface for rtemis. It is a comprehensive data science web application that provides:

Advanced visualization
Statistical Analyses
Machine Learning, including Clustering, Decomposition, Regression, and Classification

  

 



 


This website was created using Quarto.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
rtemislive is organized in modules. The user can toggle modules ON and OFF using the first drop-down menu on the top right.
Custom installations allow to specify whether a dataset should be pre-loaded and allow setting the initial state of most application settings, including modules and themes.
 The documentation on this site ir organized by module: each chapter, accessible from the navigation in the lest, corresponds to an individual module.
 rtemislive is built on top of rtemis
Data operations, including filtering, selecting and a subset of data aggregation operations, performed in real time using data.table.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1 Uploading data





Figure 2.1: rtemislive supports most popular tabular data file formats




rtemislive supports a wide range of file types, including some of the most popular tabular data formats:

General purpose: .csv, .json
R: .rds
Excel: .xlsx
Apache Arrow: .arrow, .feather, .parquet
Stata: .dta
SPSS: .por, .sav, .zsav
SAS: .xpt
Matlab: .mat

It is best to upload cleaned data.  Clean data includes:

Descriptive column names that always begin with letters (not numbers!) and contain no symbols other than underscores
Descriptive categorical levels: e.g. “Female”, “Male”, not “1”, “2”; “Control”, “Case”, not “0”, “1”)

If you have prepared a dataset in R, the most convenient way to upload to rtemislive is to use saveRD() to save to an RDS and then upload that file. This will maintain all column classes.

title: 3  Preprocessing
text:
The preprocessing module offers extensive functionality for data preprocessing. All preprocessing is performed using the rtemis preprocess() command.  Hover over any preprocess option on the right menu to display a tooltip with the corresponding description.
The following operations are available:

Data Cleaning

Remove constants
Remove duplicates

Batch Type Conversions, i.e. convert all columns of a type to another type

Character to factor
Logical to factor
Integer to numeric

Convert all variables with up to a particular number of unique values to factor
Individual variable conversion

Select a variable by name and convert to any type

Handle missing data:

Factor NA to missing: Considering all factor variables, convert missing values to a new level named “missing”. This is one way to impute categorical data
Impute missing data: Uses iterative random forest with predictive mean matching to predict missing data from available data

Add missingness: Add an indicator column for each variable that is being imputed indicating cases whose data was imputed

Complete cases: keep complete cases only

Data Transformations

Scale numeric data: Transformed all numeric columns to have a standard deviation of 1
Center numeric data: Transformed all numeric columns to have a mean of 0
One-hot encode categorical: One-hot all categorical variables

Reorder factor levels: Allows you to pick any factor in the dataset and explicitly set the order of levels. This affects the order categorical levels appear in plots, and which level is considered as the baseline in linear models.
Delete columns: Allows removing columns from your data

title: 5  Heatmap
text: The heatmap module allows plotting heatmaps of the correlation matrix of any number of continuous variables.

title: 6  Graph
text:
Graph theory module:

Visualization

igraph
NetworkD3
graphjs

title: 4  Plot
text:
This is the main plotting module. It provides support for the following plot types:

Boxplot
Histogram
Density plot
Bar plot
Scatter (2D and 3D)
Map (choropleth map)
Volcano plot

title: 2  Data
text:
2.2 View loaded data
By default, rtemislive will display the first 10 rows and the first 9 columns of data. This is to avoid slow loading of large datasets.
Use the menu on the right to:

Select which columns to show
Choose whether to paginate the table
Define number of rows to load

The data view allows you to:

Sort by any column in asceding or descending order
Search the contents of the table






Figure 2.2: The Data tab provides a spreadsheet-like view of your data, which can be sorted and searched
